name: Aphrodite
description: Goddess of beauty, love, desire, and pleasure. Although married to Hephaestus she had many lovers, most notably Ares, Adonis, and Anchises. She was depicted as an extraordinarily beautiful woman, with poets praising the radiance of her smile in particular. Her symbols include roses and other flowers, the scallop shell, and the myrtle wreath. Her sacred animals include doves and sparrows. Her Roman counterpart is Venus.

name: Apollo
description: God of music, arts, knowledge, healing, plague, prophecy, poetry, manly beauty, and archery. He is the son of Zeus and Leto, and the twin brother of Artemis. Both Apollo and Artemis use a bow and arrow. Apollo is often incorrectly identified as the god of the sun. Although Apollo is the god of the sun in Roman mythology, Helios is the god of the sun in Greek mythology. In sculpture, Apollo is depicted as a very handsome, beardless young man with long hair and an ideal physique. As the embodiment of perfectionism, he could be cruel and destructive, and his love affairs were rarely happy. He often appears in the company of the Muses. His attributes include the laurel wreath and lyre. His sacred animals include roe deer, swans, cicadas, hawks, ravens, crows, foxes, mice, and snakes. His Roman counterpart is also named Apollo

name: Ares
description: God of war, bloodshed, and violence. The son of Zeus and Hera, he was depicted as a beardless youth, either nude with a helmet and spear or sword, or as an armed warrior. Homer portrays him as moody and unreliable, and he generally represents the chaos of war in contrast to Athena, a goddess of military strategy and skill. Ares is known for cuckolding his brother Hephaestus and conducting an affair with Aphrodite. His sacred animals include vultures, venomous snakes, dogs, and boars. His Roman counterpart Mars by contrast was regarded as the dignified ancestor of the Roman people.

name: Artemis
description: Virgin goddess of the hunt, wilderness, animals, young girls, childbirth, and plague. In later times Artemis became associated with bows and arrows. She is the daughter of Zeus and Leto, and twin sister of Apollo. In art she is often depicted as a young woman dressed in a short knee-length chiton and equipped with a hunting bow and a quiver of arrows. Her attributes include hunting spears, animal pelts, deer and other wild animals. Her sacred animals include deer, bears, and wild boars. Her Roman counterpart is Diana.

name: Athena
description: Goddess of reason, wisdom, intelligence, skill, peace, warfare, battle strategy, and handicrafts. According to most traditions, she was born from Zeus's forehead, fully formed and armored. She is depicted as being crowned with a crested helm, armed with shield and spear, and wearing the aegis over a long dress. Poets describe her as "grey-eyed" or having especially bright, keen eyes. She is a special patron of heroes such as Odysseus. She is the patron of the city Athens (which was named after her) and is attributed to various inventions in arts and literature. Her symbol is the olive tree. She is commonly shown as being accompanied by her sacred animal, the owl. Her Roman counterpart is Minerva.

name: Demeter
description: Goddess of grain, agriculture, harvest, growth, and nourishment. Demeter is a daughter of Cronus and Rhea, and a sister of Zeus, by whom she bore Persephone. Demeter is one of the main deities of the Eleusinian Mysteries, in which her power over the life cycle of plants symbolizes the passage of the human soul through life and into the afterlife. She is depicted as a mature woman, often crowned and holding sheafs of wheat and a torch. Her symbols are the cornucopia, wheat-ears, the winged serpent, and the lotus staff. Her sacred animals include pigs and snakes. Her Roman counterpart is Ceres.

name: Dionysus/Bacchus
description: God of wine, fruitfulness, parties, festivals, madness, chaos, drunkenness, vegetation, and ecstasy. In art he is depicted as either an older bearded god or an effeminate, long-haired youth. His attributes include the thyrsus, a drinking cup, the grape vine, and a crown of ivy. He is often in the company of his thiasos, a group of attendants including satyrs, maenads, and his old tutor Silenus. The consort of Dionysus was Ariadne. His sacred animals include dolphins, serpents, tigers, and donkeys. A later addition to the Olympians, in some accounts he replaced Hestia. Bacchus was another name for him in Greek, and came into common usage among the Romans.

name: Hades/Pluto
description: God of the underworld and the dead. His consort is Persephone. His attributes are the drinking horn or cornucopia, key, sceptre, and the three-headed dog Cerberus. His sacred animals include the screech owl. He was one of three sons of Cronus and Rhea, and thus sovereign over one of the three realms of the universe, the underworld. As a chthonic god, however, his place among the Olympians is ambiguous. In the mystery religions and Athenian literature, Pluto ("the Rich") was his preferred name, with Hades referring to the underworld itself. The Romans translated Plouton as Dis Pater ("the Rich Father") or Pluto.

name: Hephaestus
description: God of fire, metalworking, and crafts. Either the son of Zeus and Hera or Hera alone, he is the smith of the gods and the husband of the adulterous Aphrodite. He was usually depicted as a bearded, crippled man with hammer, tongs, and anvil, and sometimes riding a donkey. His sacred animals include the donkey, the guard dog, and the crane. Among his creations was the armor of Achilles. Hephaestus used the fire of the forge as a creative force, but his Roman counterpart Vulcan was feared for his destructive potential and associated with the volcanic power of the earth.

name: Hera
description: Queen of the gods, and goddess of marriage, women, childbirth, heirs, kings, and empires. She is the wife and sister of Zeus, and the daughter of Cronus and Rhea. She was usually depicted as a regal woman in the prime of her life, wearing a diadem and veil and holding a lotus-tipped staff. Although she is the goddess of marriage, Zeus's many infidelities drive her to jealousy and vengefulness. Her sacred animals include the heifer, the peacock, and the cuckoo. Her Roman counterpart is Juno.

name: Hermes
description: God of boundaries, travel, communication, trade, language, and writing. The son of Zeus and Maia, Hermes is the messenger of the gods, and a psychopomp who leads the souls of the dead into the afterlife. He was depicted either as a handsome and athletic beardless youth, or as an older bearded man. His attributes include the herald's wand or caduceus, winged sandals, and a traveler's cap. His sacred animals include the tortoise. His Roman counterpart is Mercury.

name: Hestia
description: Virgin goddess of the hearth, home, and chastity. She is a daughter of Rhea and Cronus, and a sister of Zeus. Not often identifiable in Greek art, she appeared as a modestly veiled woman. Her symbols are the hearth and kettle. In some accounts, she gave up her seat as one of the Twelve Olympians in favor of Dionysus, and she plays little role in Greek myths. Her Roman counterpart Vesta, however, was a major deity of the Roman state.

name: Poseidon
description: God of the sea, rivers, floods, droughts, and earthquakes. He is a son of Cronus and Rhea, and the brother of Zeus and Hades. He rules one of the three realms of the universe, as king of the sea and the waters. In art he is depicted as a mature man of sturdy build, often with a luxuriant beard, and holding a trident. His sacred animals include the horse and the dolphin. His wedding with Amphitrite is often presented as a triumphal procession. In some stories he rapes Medusa, leading to her transformation into a hideous Gorgon and also to the birth of their two children, Pegasus and Chrysaor. His Roman counterpart is Neptune.

name: Zeus
description: King of the gods, ruler of Mount Olympus, and god of the sky, weather, thunder, lightning, law, order, and justice. He is the youngest son of Cronus and Rhea. He overthrew Cronus and gained the sovereignty of heaven for himself. In art he is depicted as a regal, mature man with a sturdy figure and dark beard. His usual attributes are the royal scepter and the lightning bolt. His sacred animals include the eagle and the bull. His Roman counterpart is Jupiter, also known as Jove.

name: Coeus
description: Titan of intellect and the axis of heaven around which the constellations revolved.

name: Crius
description: The least individualized of the Twelve Titans, he is the father of Astraeus, Pallas, and Perses. Implied to be the Titan of constellations.

name: Cronus
description: Titan of harvests and personification of destructive time. The leader of the Titans, who overthrew his father Uranus only to be overthrown in turn by his son, Zeus. Not to be confused with Chronos.

name: Hyperion
description: Titan of light. With Theia, he is the father of Helios (the sun), Selene (the moon), and Eos (the dawn).

name: Iapetus
description: Titan of mortality and father of Prometheus, Epimetheus, Menoetius, and Atlas.

name: Mnemosyne
description: Titaness of memory and remembrance, and mother of the Nine Muses.

name: Oceanus
description: Titan of the all-encircling river Oceans around the earth, the fount of all the Earth's fresh-water.

name: Phoebe
description: Titaness of the "bright" intellect and prophecy, and consort of Koios.

name: Rhea
description: Titaness of fertility, motherhood and the mountain wilds. She is the sister and consort of Cronus, and mother of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera, Demeter, and Hestia.

name: Tethys
description: Titaness of fresh-water, and the mother of the rivers, springs, streams, fountains, and clouds.

name: Theia
description: Titaness of sight and the shining light of the clear blue sky. She is the consort of Hyperion, and mother of Helios, Selene, and Eos.

name: Themis
description: Titaness of divine law and order.

name: Asteria
description: Titaness of nocturnal oracles and falling stars.

name: Astraeus
description: Titan of dusk, stars, and planets, and the art of astrology.

name: Atlas
description: Titan forced to carry the heavens upon his shoulders by Zeus. Also Son of Iapetus.

name: Aura
description: Titaness of the breeze and the fresh, cool air of early morning.

name: Clymene
description: Titaness of renown, fame, and infamy, and wife of Iapetus.

name: Dione
description: Titaness of the oracle of Dodona.

name: Helios
description: Titan of the sun and guardian of oaths.

name: Selene
description: Titaness of the moon.

name: Eos
description: Titaness of the dawn.

name: Epimetheus
description: Titan of afterthought and the father of excuses.

name: Eurybia
description: Titaness of the mastery of the seas and consort of Krios.

name: Eurynome
description: Titaness of water-meadows and pasturelands, and mother of the three Charites by Zeus.

name: Lelantos
description: Titan of air and the hunter's skill of stalking prey. He is the male counterpart of Leto.

name: Leto
description: Titaness of motherhood and mother of the twin Olympians, Artemis and Apollo.

name: Menoetius
description: Titan of violent anger, rash action, and human mortality. Killed by Zeus.

name: Metis
description: Titaness of good counsel, advice, planning, cunning, craftiness, and wisdom. Mother of Athena.

name: Ophion
description: An elder Titan, in some versions of the myth he ruled the Earth with his consort Eurynome before Cronus overthrew him. Another account describes him as a snake, born from the "World Egg"

name: Pallas
description: Titan of warcraft. He was killed by Athena during the Titanomachy.

name: Perses
description: Titan of destruction.

name: Prometheus
description: Titan of forethought and crafty counsel, and creator of mankind.

name: Styx
description: Titaness of the Underworld river Styx and personification of hatred.

name: Agrius
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by the Moirai (Fates) with bronze clubs.

name: Alcyoneus
description: According to Apollodorus, he was (along with Porphyrion), the greatest of the Giants; immortal while fighting in his native land, he was dragged from his homeland and killed by Heracles. According to Pindar, he was a herdsman, and in a separate battle from the Gigantomachy was killed by Heracles and Telamon, while they were traveling through Phlegra. Representations of Heracles fighting Alcyoneus are found on many sixth century BC and later works of art.

name: Alektos/Allektos
description: Named on the late sixth century Siphnian Treasury (Alektos), and the second century BC Pergamon Altar (Allektos).

name: Aristaeus
description: According to the Suda, he was the only Giant to "survive". He Is probably named on an Attic black-figure dinos by Lydos (Akropolis 607) dating from the second quarter of the sixth century BC, fighting Hephaestus.

name: Asterius/Astarias/Aster
description: ("Bright One" or "Glitterer"): A Giant, also called Aster, killed by Athena, whose death, according to some accounts, was celebrated by the Panathenaea. Probably the same as the Giant Astarias named on the late sixth century Siphnian Treasury. Probably also the same as Asterus, mentioned in the epic poem Meropis, as an invulnerable warrior killed by Athena. In the poem, Heracles, fighting the Meropes, a race of Giants, on the Island of Kos, would have been killed but for Athena's intervention. Athena kills and flays Asterus and uses his impenetrable skin for her aegis. Other accounts name others whose hyde provided Athena's aegis: Apollodrus has Athena flay the Giant Pallas, while Euripides' Ion has Gorgon, here considered to be a Giant, as Athena's victim.

name: Clytius
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by Hecate with her torches.

name: Enceladus
description: Euripides has Athena fighting him with her "Gorgon shield" (her aegis). According to Apollodorus, he was crushed by Athena under the Island of Sicily. Virgil has him struck by Zeus' lightning bolt, and both Virgil and Claudian have him buried under Mount Etna, (other traditions had Typhon or Briareus buried under Etna). For some Enceladus was instead buried in Italy.

name: Ephialtes
description: (probably different from the Aload Giant who was also named Ephialtes): According to Apollodorus he was blinded by arrows from Apollo and Heracles. He is named on three Attic black-figure pots (Akropolis 2134, Getty 81.AE.211, Louvre E732) dating from the second quarter of the sixth century BC. On Louvre E732, he is, along with Hyperbios and Agasthenes, opposed by Zeus, while on Getty 81.AE.211, his opponents are apparently Apollo and Artemis. He is also named on the late sixth century BC Siphnian Treasury, where he is probably one of the opponents of Apollo and Artemis, and probably as well on what might be the earliest representation of the Gigantomachy, a pinax fragment from Eleusis (Eleusis 349). He is also named on a late fifth century BC cup from Vulci (Berlin F2531), shown battling Apollo. Although the usual opponent of Poseidon among the Giants is Polybotes, one early fifth century red-figure column krater (Vienna 688) has Poseidon attacking Ephialtes.

name: Euryalus
description: He is named on a late sixth century red-figure cup (Akropolis 2.211) and an early fifth century red-figure cup (British Museum E 47) fighting Hephaestos.

name: Eurymedon
description: According to Homer, he was a king of the Giants and father of Periboea (mother of Nausithous, king of the Phaeacians, by Poseidon), who "brought destruction on his froward people". He was possibly the Eurymedon who raped Hera producing Prometheus as offspring. He is probably named on Akropolis 2134. He is possibly mentioned by the Latin poet Propertius as an opponent of Jove.

name: Eurytus
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by Dionysus with his thyrsus.

name: Gration
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by Artemis.

name: Hopladamas (or Hopladamus)
description: : Possibly named (as Hoplodamas) on two vases dating from the second quarter of the sixth century BC, on one (Akropolis 607) being speared by Apollo, while on the other (Getty 81.AE.211) attacking Zeus. Mentioned (as Hopladamus) by the geographer Pausanias as being a leader of Giants enlisted by the Titaness Rhea, pregnant with Zeus, to defend herself from her husband Cronus.

name: Hippolytus
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by Hermes, who was wearing Hades' helmet, which made its wearer invisible.

name: Lion or Leon
description: Possibly a Giant, he is mentioned by Photius (as ascribed to Ptolemy Hephaestion) as a giant who was challenged to single combat by Heracles and killed. Lion-headed Giants are shown on the Gigantomachy frieze of the second century BC Pergamon Altar.

name: Mimas/Mimon/Mimos
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by Hephaestus. Euripides has Zeus burning him "to ashes" with his thunderbolt. According to others he was killed by Ares. "Mimos"—possibly in error for "Mimas"—is inscribed (retrograde) on Akropolis 607. He was said to be buried under Prochyte. Mimas is possibly the same as the Giant named Mimon on the late sixth century BC Siphnian Treasury, as well as on a late fifth century BC cup from Vulci (Berlin F2531) shown fighting Ares. Several depictions in Greek art, though, show Aphrodite as the opponent of Mimas.

name: Pallas
description: According to Apollodorus, he was flayed by Athena, who used his skin as a shield. Other accounts name others whose hyde provided Athena's aegis: the epic poem Meropis has Athena kill and flay the Giant Asterus while Euripides' Ion has Gorgon, here considered to be a Giant, as Athena's victim. Claudian names him as one of several Giants turned to stone by Minerva's Gorgon shield.

name: Pelorus
description: According to Claudian, he was killed by Mars, the Roman equivalent of Ares.

name: Picolous
description: A Gigas who had become infatuated with Circe and attempted to capture her, only to be killed by Helios. It is said that the legendary moly plant first sprang forth from Picolous' blood as it seeped into the ground.

name: Polybotes
description: According to Apollodorus, he was crushed under Nisyros, a piece of the island of Kos broken off and thrown by Poseidon. He is named on two sixth century BC pots, on one (Getty 81.AE.211) he is opposed by Zeus, on the other (Louvre E732) he is opposed by Poseidon carrying Nisyros on his shoulder.

name: Porphyrion
description: According to Apollodorus, he was (along with Alcyoneus), the greatest of the Giants, he attacked Heracles and Hera but Zeus "smote him with a thunderbolt, and Hercules shot him dead with an arrow." According to Pindar, who calls him "king of the Giants", he was slain by an arrow from the bow of Apollo. He is named on a late fifth century BC cup from Vulci (Berlin F2531), where he is battling with Zeus. He was also probably named on the late sixth century BC Siphnian Treasury.

name: Thoas/Thoon
description: According to Apollodorus, he was killed by the Moirai (Fates) with bronze clubs.

name: Otus/Otos (Aloadae)
description: twin giants who attempted to climb to Olympus by piling mountains on top of each other.

name: Ephialtes (Aloadae)
description: twin giants who attempted to climb to Olympus by piling mountains on top of each other.

name: Anax
description: was a giant of the island of Lade near Miletos in Lydia, Anatolia.

name: Antaeus
description: a Libyan giant who wrestled all visitors to the death until he was slain by Heracles

name: Antiphates
description: the king of the man-eating giants known as Laestrygones which were encountered by Odysseus on his travels.

name: Argus Panoptes
description: a hundred-eyed giant tasked with guarding over Io

name: Asterius
description: a Lydian giant.

name: Cacus
description: a fire-breathing Latin giant slain by Heracles.

name: Arges (Elder Cyclopes)
description: One of three one-eyed giants who forged the lightning-bolts of Zeus, Trident of Poseidon and Helmet of Hades

name: Brontes (Elder Cyclopes)
description: One of three one-eyed giants who forged the lightning-bolts of Zeus, Trident of Poseidon and Helmet of Hades

name: Steropes (Elder Cyclopes)
description: One of three one-eyed giants who forged the lightning-bolts of Zeus, Trident of Poseidon and Helmet of Hades

name: Polyphemus
description: a cyclops who briefly captured Odysseus and his men, only to be overcome and blinded by the hero

name: Gegenees
description: a tribe of six-armed giants fought by the Argonauts on Bear Mountain in Mysia

name: Geryon
description: a three-bodied giant who dwelt on the sunset isle at the ends of the earth. He was slain by Heracles when the hero arrived to fetch the giant's cattle as one of his twelve labours.

name: Hekatonkheires
description: the Hundred-Handed Ones, giant gods of violent storms and hurricanes. Three sons of Uranus and Gaia, each with their own distinct characters.

name: Briareus
description: or Aigaion (Αἰγαίων), The Vigorous - see [Hekatonkheires]

name: Cottus
description: The Furious - see [Hekatonkheires]

name: Gyges
description: The Big-Limbed - see [Hekatonkheires]

name: Laestrygonians
description: a tribe of man-eating giants encountered by Odysseus on his travels

name: Orion
description: a giant huntsman whom Zeus placed among the stars as the constellation of Orion

name: Talos
description: a giant forged from bronze by Hephaestus, and given by Zeus to his lover Europa as her personal protector

name: Tityos
description: a giant slain by Apollo and Artemis when he attempted to violate their mother Leto.

name: Typhon
description: a monstrous immortal storm-giant who attempted to launch an attack on Mt. Olympus but was defeated by the Olympians and imprisoned in the pits of Tartarus

name: Achlys
description: spirit of the death-mist, personification of sadness, misery and poison

name: Adephagia
description: spirit of satiety and gluttony

name: Adikia
description: spirit of injustice and wrongdoing

name: Aergia
description: spirit of idleness, laziness, indolence and sloth

name: Agon
description: spirit of contest, who possessed an altar at Olympia, site of the Olympic Games.

name: Aidos
description: spirit of modesty, reverence and respect

name: Aisa
description: personification of lot and fate

name: Alala
description: spirit of the war cry

name: Alastor
description: spirit of blood feuds and vengeance

name: Aletheia
description: spirit of truth, truthfulness and sincerity

name: Algea
description: spirits of pain and suffering

name: Achos
description: trouble, distress

name: Ania
description: ache, anguish

name: Lupe
description: pain, grief, sadness

name: Alke
description: spirit of prowess and courage

name: Amechania
description: spirit of helplessness and want of means

name: Amphilogiai
description: spirits of disputes, debate, and contention

name: Anaideia
description: spirit of ruthlessness, shamelessness, and unforgivingness

name: Androktasiai
description: spirits of battlefield slaughter

name: Angelia
description: spirit of messages, tidings and proclamations

name: Apate
description: spirit of deceit, guile, fraud and deception

name: Apheleia
description: spirit of simplicity

name: Aporia
description: spirit of difficulty, perplexity, powerlessness, and want of means

name: Arae
description: spirits of curses

name: Arete
description: spirit of virtue, excellence, goodness, and valour

name: Atë
description: spirit of delusion, infatuation, blind folly, recklessness, and ruin

name: Bia (Violence)
description: the personification of force and raw energy

name: Caerus
description: spirit of opportunity

name: Corus
description: spirit of surfeit

name: Deimos
description: spirit of fear, dread, and terror

name: Dikaiosyne
description: spirit of justice and righteousness

name: Dike
description: spirit of justice, fair judgement, and the rights established by custom and law

name: Dolos
description: spirit of trickery, cunning deception, craftiness, treachery, and guile

name: Dysnomia
description: spirit of lawlessness and poor civil constitution

name: Dyssebeia
description: spirit of impiety

name: Eirene
description: goddess of peace

name: Ekecheiria
description: spirit of truce, armistice, and the cessation of all hostilities; honoured at the Olympic Games

name: Eleos
description: spirit of mercy, pity, and compassion

name: Elpis
description: spirit of hope and expectation

name: Epiphron
description: spirit of prudence, shrewdness, thoughtfulness, carefulness, and sagacity

name: Eris
description: spirit of strife, discord, contention, and rivalry

name: Anteros
description: god of requited love

name: Eros
description: god of love and sexual intercourse

name: Hedylogos
description: god of sweet talk and flattery

name: Hermaphroditus
description: god of hermaphrodites, effeminate men and androgyny

name: Himeros
description: god of sexual desire

name: Hymen/Hymenaeus
description: god of marriage ceremonies, inspiring feasts and song

name: Pothos
description: god of sexual longing, yearning, and desire

name: Eucleia
description: spirit of good repute and glory

name: Eulabeia
description: spirit of discretion, caution, and circumspection

name: Eunomia
description: goddess of good order and lawful conduct

name: Eupheme
description: spirit of words of good omen, acclamation, praise, applause, and shouts of triumph

name: Eupraxia
description: spirit of well-being

name: Eusebeia
description: spirit of piety, loyalty, duty, and filial respect

name: Euthenia
description: spirit of prosperity, abundance, and plenty

name: Gelos
description: spirit of laughter

name: Geras
description: spirit of old age

name: Harmonia
description: goddess of harmony and concord

name: Hebe
description: goddess of youth

name: Hedone
description: spirit of pleasure, enjoyment, and delight

name: Heimarmene
description: personification of share destined by fate

name: Homados
description: spirit of the din of battle

name: Homonoia
description: spirit of concord, unanimity, and oneness of mind

name: Horkos
description: spirit of oaths

name: Horme
description: spirit of impulse or effort (to do a thing), eagerness, setting oneself in motion, and starting an action

name: Hybris
description: spirit of outrageous behaviour

name: Hypnos
description: god of sleep

name: Hysminai
description: spirits of fighting and combat

name: Ioke
description: spirit of pursuit in battle

name: Kakia
description: spirit of vice and moral badness

name: Kalokagathia
description: spirit of nobility

name: Keres
description: spirit of violent or cruel death

name: Koalemos
description: spirit of stupidity and foolishness

name: Kratos
description: spirit of strength, might, power, and sovereign rule

name: Kydoimos
description: spirit of the din of battle, confusion, uproar, and hubbub

name: Lethe
description: spirit of forgetfulness and oblivion, and of the river of the same name

name: Limos
description: spirit of hunger and starvation

name: Litae
description: spirits of prayer

name: Lyssa
description: spirit of rage, fury and rabies in animals

name: Machai
description: spirits of fighting and combat

name: Mania
description: spirit or spirits of madness, insanity, and frenzy

name: Clotho
description: the spinner of the life thread

name: Lachesis
description: the measurer of the life thread

name: Atropos
description: the severer of the life thread

name: Momus
description: spirit of mockery, blame, censure and stinging criticism

name: Moros
description: spirit of doom

name: Neikea
description: spirits of quarrels, feuds and grievances

name: Nemesis
description: goddess of revenge, balance, righteous indignation, and retribution

name: Nike
description: goddess of victory

name: Nomos
description: spirit of law

name: Oizys
description: spirit of woe and misery

name: Oneiroi
description: spirits of dreams

name: Epiales
description: spirit of nightmares

name: Morpheus
description: god of dreams, who takes shape of humans

name: Phantasos
description: spirit of dreams of fantasy, who takes shape of inanimate objects

name: Phobetor/Icelos
description: spirit of nightmares, who takes shape of animals

name: Palioxis
description: spirit of backrush, flight and retreat from battle

name: Peitharchia
description: spirit of obedience

name: Peitho
description: spirit of persuasion and seduction

name: Penia
description: spirit of poverty and need

name: Penthus
description: spirit of grief, mourning, and lamentation

name: Pepromene
description: personification of the destined share, similar to Heimarmene

name: Pheme
description: spirit of rumour, report, and gossip

name: Philophrosyne
description: spirit of friendliness, kindness, and welcome

name: Philotes
description: spirit of friendship, affection, and sexual intercourse

name: Phobos
description: spirit of panic fear, flight, and battlefield rout

name: Phonoi
description: spirits of murder, killing, and slaughter

name: Phrike
description: spirit of horror and trembling fear

name: Phthonus
description: spirit of envy and jealousy

name: Pistis
description: spirit of trust, honesty, and good faith

name: Poine
description: spirit of retribution, vengeance, recompense, punishment, and penalty for the crime of murder and manslaughter

name: Polemos
description: personification of war

name: Ponos
